title: Add structured logging with levels (debug/info/warn/error)
description:
## Problem

Current logging uses `log.Printf` with emoji prefixes (✅ ⚠️) but lacks:
- Log levels (debug, info, warn, error)
- Structured fields (JSON output for machines)
- Filtering by severity
- Consistent format across all modules
- Machine-parseable output for monitoring

## Current Logging Style

```go
log.Printf("✅ Processed %s in %s", app.ID, time.Since(appStart))
log.Printf("⚠️  Failed to fetch details for %s: %v", appID, err)
```

**Issues**:
- No way to filter by severity
- Hard to parse by log aggregators
- Emoji may not render in all environments
- No contextual metadata (request ID, correlation)

## Proposed Solution

### Option 1: Use slog (Go standard library, Go 1.21+)
```go
import "log/slog"

// Setup
logger := slog.New(slog.NewJSONHandler(os.Stdout, &slog.HandlerOptions{
    Level: slog.LevelInfo,
}))

// Usage
logger.Info("Processed app",
    "app_id", app.ID,
    "duration_ms", time.Since(appStart).Milliseconds(),
    "package_type", app.PackageType,
)

logger.Error("Failed to fetch details",
    "app_id", appID,
    "error", err,
    "url", url,
    "status_code", statusCode,
)

logger.Debug("API request",
    "method", "GET",
    "url", url,
    "headers", headers,
)
```

**Output**:
```json
{"time":"2026-02-08T20:00:00Z","level":"INFO","msg":"Processed app","app_id":"org.gnome.Calculator","duration_ms":125,"package_type":"flatpak"}
{"time":"2026-02-08T20:00:01Z","level":"ERROR","msg":"Failed to fetch details","app_id":"org.example.App","error":"timeout","url":"https://flathub.org/api/v2/appstream/org.example.App","status_code":0}
```

### Option 2: Use zerolog (faster, more features)
```go
import "github.com/rs/zerolog/log"

log.Info().
    Str("app_id", app.ID).
    Dur("duration", time.Since(appStart)).
    Str("package_type", app.PackageType).
    Msg("Processed app")

log.Error().
    Err(err).
    Str("app_id", appID).
    Str("url", url).
    Int("status_code", statusCode).
    Msg("Failed to fetch details")
```

## Migration Strategy

### Phase 1: Add structured logger alongside existing logs
```go
// internal/logging/logger.go
package logging

import "log/slog"

var Logger *slog.Logger

func Init(level slog.Level) {
    opts := &slog.HandlerOptions{Level: level}
    Logger = slog.New(slog.NewJSONHandler(os.Stdout, opts))
}

func Info(msg string, args ...any) {
    Logger.Info(msg, args...)
}

func Error(msg string, err error, args ...any) {
    Logger.Error(msg, append([]any{"error", err}, args...)...)
}
```

### Phase 2: Update all modules
```go
// Before
log.Printf("✅ Processed %s in %s", app.ID, time.Since(appStart))

// After
logging.Info("Processed app",
    "app_id", app.ID,
    "duration", time.Since(appStart),
)
```

### Phase 3: Remove old log.Printf calls

## Log Levels

- **DEBUG**: Detailed traces (API requests/responses, cache hits)
- **INFO**: Normal operations (apps processed, builds completed)
- **WARN**: Non-critical issues (app fetch failed, fallback used)
- **ERROR**: Critical errors (pipeline failed, invalid config)

## Environment Variable Control

```bash
# Set log level
export LOG_LEVEL=debug  # debug, info, warn, error
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go

# Human-readable format (development)
export LOG_FORMAT=console
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go

# JSON format (production, default)
export LOG_FORMAT=json
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go
```

## Benefits

- **Filtering**: Show only errors during debugging
- **Monitoring**: Parse logs with Loki, ELK, or Datadog
- **Performance**: Debug logs can be disabled in production
- **Context**: Structured fields provide rich metadata
- **Standards**: Follows industry best practices
- **Search**: Easier to query logs (e.g., "show all 429 errors")

## Example: Filtering Logs

```bash
# Show only errors
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go 2>&1 | jq 'select(.level == "ERROR")'

# Show slow operations (>1s)
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go 2>&1 | jq 'select(.duration_ms > 1000)'

# Show specific app
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go 2>&1 | jq 'select(.app_id == "org.gnome.Calculator")'
```

## Implementation Checklist

- [ ] Add slog or zerolog to go.mod
- [ ] Create internal/logging package
- [ ] Add LOG_LEVEL environment variable support
- [ ] Update main.go to initialize logger
- [ ] Migrate flathub package
- [ ] Migrate homebrew package
- [ ] Migrate github/gitlab packages
- [ ] Update documentation
- [ ] Remove old log.Printf calls

## Recommendation

Use **slog** (standard library):
- No external dependencies
- Good enough for most needs
- Future-proof (part of Go stdlib)
- Easy migration path

Use **zerolog** only if:
- Need highest performance
- Want colored console output
- Need advanced features (sampling, hooks)

title: Improve error messages with actionable debugging hints
description:
## Problem

Many error messages are generic and don't provide enough context for debugging. When pipeline failures occur, developers waste time investigating.

## Examples of Poor Error Messages

### 1. Flathub API (flathub.go:137)
```go
log.Printf("⚠️  Failed to fetch details for %s: %v", flathubApp.AppID, err)
```
**Issue**: No URL, no HTTP status code, no retry indication

**Better**:
```go
log.Printf("⚠️  Failed to fetch Flathub details for %s (URL: %s, status: %d, attempt %d/%d): %v",
    appID, url, statusCode, attempt, maxAttempts, err)
```

### 2. GitHub rate limit (releases.go:67)
```go
return nil, fmt.Errorf("rate limit exceeded (403) - consider setting GITHUB_TOKEN environment variable")
```
**Issue**: Doesn't show how many requests remain, when limit resets

**Better**:
```go
rateLimitReset := resp.Header.Get("X-RateLimit-Reset")
remaining := resp.Header.Get("X-RateLimit-Remaining")
return nil, fmt.Errorf("GitHub rate limit exceeded: %s/%s requests used, resets at %s. Set GITHUB_TOKEN for higher limits (5000/hour)",
    remaining, resp.Header.Get("X-RateLimit-Limit"), time.Unix(rateLimitReset, 0))
```

### 3. Brewfile parsing (flatpaks.go:61)
```go
log.Printf("⚠️  Failed to fetch %s: %v", brewfile, err)
```
**Issue**: Doesn't indicate if this is a network error, 404, or permission issue

**Better**:
```go
if resp.StatusCode == 404 {
    log.Printf("⚠️  Brewfile not found: %s (Did the path change in projectbluefin/common?)", brewfile)
} else if resp.StatusCode == 403 {
    log.Printf("⚠️  Rate limited fetching %s. Set GITHUB_TOKEN to increase limits.", brewfile)
} else {
    log.Printf("⚠️  Network error fetching %s: %v (Retry in 5s)", brewfile, err)
}
```

### 4. JSON unmarshaling (models.go:162)
```go
return fmt.Errorf("field must be string or array")
```
**Issue**: Doesn't show which field or what the actual value was

**Better**:
```go
return fmt.Errorf("field must be string or array, got: %T (value: %q)", data, string(data))
```

## Proposed Improvements

### Error Message Template
Every error should include:
1. **What failed**: Clear description
2. **Why it failed**: Root cause or error type
3. **Where it failed**: File/line or URL
4. **How to fix**: Actionable suggestion

### Example Template
```go
func betterError(operation, resource, reason, remedy string) error {
    return fmt.Errorf("%s failed for %s: %s. Try: %s", operation, resource, reason, remedy)
}

// Usage
return betterError(
    "Fetch GitHub releases",
    "ublue-os/bluefin",
    "rate limit exceeded (0/60 requests remaining, resets in 45m)",
    "Set GITHUB_TOKEN environment variable for 5000/hour limit",
)
```

### HTTP Error Helper
```go
func describeHTTPError(resp *http.Response, url string) string {
    switch resp.StatusCode {
    case 404:
        return fmt.Sprintf("Resource not found: %s (Check if URL changed)", url)
    case 403:
        remaining := resp.Header.Get("X-RateLimit-Remaining")
        if remaining == "0" {
            reset := resp.Header.Get("X-RateLimit-Reset")
            resetTime := time.Unix(reset, 0)
            return fmt.Sprintf("Rate limit exceeded, resets at %s", resetTime)
        }
        return fmt.Sprintf("Forbidden: %s (Check API token permissions)", url)
    case 500, 502, 503:
        return fmt.Sprintf("Server error (%d): %s (Retrying...)", resp.StatusCode, url)
    case 408:
        return fmt.Sprintf("Timeout: %s (Try increasing timeout or check network)", url)
    default:
        return fmt.Sprintf("HTTP %d: %s", resp.StatusCode, url)
    }
}
```

## Files to Update

1. internal/flathub/flathub.go (API errors)
2. internal/bluefin/homebrew.go (formula fetch errors)
3. internal/bluefin/flatpaks.go (Brewfile fetch errors)
4. internal/github/github.go (rate limit errors)
5. internal/gitlab/gitlab.go (API errors)
6. internal/models/models.go (JSON errors)
7. cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go (top-level errors)

## Benefits

- Faster debugging (know exactly what went wrong)
- Reduced support burden (users can self-help)
- Better logs for monitoring/alerting
- Professional quality error handling
- Easier onboarding for new contributors

## Testing

Add test cases for error scenarios:
```go

    tests := []struct {
        statusCode int
        wantContains []string
    }{
        {404, []string{"not found", "Check if URL changed"}},
        {403, []string{"Rate limit", "GITHUB_TOKEN"}},
        {500, []string{"Server error", "Retrying"}},
    }
    // ...
}
```

title: Add retry logic and timeout handling for external API calls
description:
## Problem

All HTTP clients (Flathub, Homebrew, GitHub, GitLab) lack retry logic for transient failures. This makes the pipeline fragile to:
- Network timeouts
- Rate limit errors (429)
- Service unavailability (503)
- Connection resets

## Affected Files

- internal/flathub/flathub.go: FetchRecentlyUpdated, FetchAppDetails (lines 246-300)
- internal/bluefin/homebrew.go: fetchHomebrewPackageMetadata (line 111-132)
- internal/bluefin/flatpaks.go: fetchRawFile (lines 94-130)
- internal/github/github.go: fetchGitHubReleases (lines 76-124)
- internal/gitlab/gitlab.go: fetchGitLabReleases (lines 85-189)

## Current Behavior

Single HTTP request with basic timeout:
```go
client := &http.Client{Timeout: 10 * time.Second}
resp, err := client.Do(req)
if err != nil {
    return nil, fmt.Errorf("fetch metadata: %w", err)
}
```

If the request fails, the entire app/package is skipped with no retry.

## Proposed Solution

### Option 1: Use existing retry library (hashicorp/go-retryablehttp)
```go
import "github.com/hashicorp/go-retryablehttp"

retryClient := retryablehttp.NewClient()
retryClient.RetryMax = 3
retryClient.RetryWaitMin = 1 * time.Second
retryClient.RetryWaitMax = 5 * time.Second
retryClient.CheckRetry = retryablehttp.DefaultRetryPolicy

resp, err := retryClient.Do(req)
```

### Option 2: Custom retry with exponential backoff
```go
func doWithRetry(req *http.Request, maxRetries int) (*http.Response, error) {
    var resp *http.Response
    var err error
    
    client := &http.Client{Timeout: 10 * time.Second}
    
    for i := 0; i < maxRetries; i++ {
        resp, err = client.Do(req)
        if err == nil && resp.StatusCode < 500 {
            return resp, nil
        }
        
        if resp != nil {
            resp.Body.Close()
        }
        
        if i < maxRetries-1 {
            waitTime := time.Duration(math.Pow(2, float64(i))) * time.Second
            log.Printf("Retry %d/%d after %v", i+1, maxRetries, waitTime)
            time.Sleep(waitTime)
        }
    }
    
    return resp, err
}
```

## Retry Strategy

- **Max retries**: 3 attempts
- **Backoff**: Exponential (1s, 2s, 4s)
- **Retryable status codes**: 408, 429, 500, 502, 503, 504
- **Non-retryable**: 400, 401, 403, 404 (client errors)
- **Timeout per request**: 10s

## Benefits

- More resilient to transient failures
- Better user experience (fewer failed builds)
- Aligns with cloud-native best practices
- Reduces alert noise from intermittent issues

## Implementation Notes

- Add retry package to go.mod
- Create helper function to wrap all HTTP clients
- Log retry attempts for debugging
- Consider circuit breaker pattern for repeated failures

title: Add RSS feed validation and testing
Add caching layer to reduce API calls and improve build times
description:
## Problem

Every pipeline run fetches all data from scratch, even if most data hasn't changed. With 96 packages and multiple API calls per package, this:
- Takes 20-30 seconds per build
- Wastes API rate limits
- Increases risk of hitting rate limits
- Slows down development iteration

## Current Performance

From main.go logs and README:
- Flatpak fetch: ~600-800ms (42 apps, parallel)
- Homebrew fetch: ~200-300ms (44 packages, parallel)
- OS releases: ~300ms
- GitHub enrichment: ~10-20s (rate-limited)
- GitLab enrichment: ~2-5s
- **Total**: ~20-30s per build

## Proposed Solution

### Cache Strategy

**Cache Key**: App ID + Last-Modified timestamp
**Cache Location**: Local file system (.cache/ directory)
**Cache Duration**: 6 hours (matches GitHub Actions schedule)
**Cache Format**: JSON per app

### Implementation

```go
// internal/cache/cache.go
type Cache struct {
    Dir string
    TTL time.Duration
}

func (c *Cache) Get(key string, dest interface{}) error {
    path := filepath.Join(c.Dir, key+".json")
    
    // Check if file exists and is fresh
    info, err := os.Stat(path)
    if err != nil || time.Since(info.ModTime()) > c.TTL {
        return ErrCacheMiss
    }
    
    data, err := os.ReadFile(path)
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    return json.Unmarshal(data, dest)
}

func (c *Cache) Set(key string, value interface{}) error {
    path := filepath.Join(c.Dir, key+".json")
    os.MkdirAll(c.Dir, 0755)
    
    data, err := json.MarshalIndent(value, "", "  ")
    if err != nil {
        return err
    }
    
    return os.WriteFile(path, data, 0644)
}
```

### Cache Integration Points

1. **Flathub app details**: Cache by app ID
2. **Homebrew formula metadata**: Cache by formula name
3. **GitHub releases**: Cache by repo (owner/repo)
4. **GitLab releases**: Cache by project path
5. **Bluefin OS releases**: Cache by repository

### Cache Invalidation

- **Time-based**: Expire after TTL
- **Manual**: `--no-cache` flag to force refresh
- **Conditional requests**: Use If-Modified-Since headers when API supports it

### Expected Improvements

With 80% cache hit rate:
- Flatpak: 800ms → 200ms (75% reduction)
- Homebrew: 300ms → 100ms (67% reduction)
- GitHub enrichment: 20s → 5s (75% reduction)
- **Total**: 30s → 8s (73% reduction)

Development builds with warm cache: **~2-3s**

## Benefits

- Faster development iteration
- Reduced API rate limit pressure
- Lower risk of build failures
- Better local development experience
- Respects external API resources

## Considerations

- Cache directory should be in .gitignore
- GitHub Actions: Cache action can persist .cache/ between runs
- Add cache stats to build logs (hit rate, time saved)
- Consider using ETag/If-Modified-Since for smarter caching

description:
## Problem

AGENTS.md and README.md cover deployment well, but lack:
- Common error scenarios and fixes
- Troubleshooting guide for pipeline failures
- Environment setup details (Go version, Node version, required tools)
- How to debug Astro build issues
- How to test changes locally before committing

## Missing Documentation

### 1. Troubleshooting Guide

Create **TROUBLESHOOTING.md** with common issues:

```markdown
# Troubleshooting Guide

## Pipeline Failures

### "Failed to fetch Flathub apps"
**Cause**: Rate limit or network timeout
**Fix**: Set GITHUB_TOKEN or wait for rate limit reset
```bash
export GITHUB_TOKEN=ghp_your_token_here
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go
```

### "Homebrew package not found"
**Cause**: Package is macOS-only or custom tap
**Fix**: Check package in Homebrew API, may need source-overrides.json

### "OS release parsing failed"
**Cause**: Release note format changed
**Fix**: Update regex in internal/bluefin/releases.go parseOSInfo()

## Build Failures

### "Astro build failed: Cannot find module"
**Fix**: 
```bash
rm -rf node_modules package-lock.json
npm install
npm run build
```

### "Go build failed: missing go.sum entry"
**Fix**:
```bash
go mod tidy
go mod download
```

## Data Quality Issues

### "Apps show wrong release date"
**Cause**: Date parsing fallback to time.Now()
**Fix**: Check Flathub API response for timestamp field

### "GitHub releases missing"
**Cause**: No GITHUB_TOKEN set
**Fix**: Generate token at https://github.com/settings/tokens
```

Expand README.md with detailed setup:

```markdown
## Development Setup

### Prerequisites

**Required versions**:
- Go: 1.23 or later
- Node.js: 20.x or later (check: `node --version`)
- npm: 10.x or later (check: `npm --version`)

**Optional but recommended**:
- GitHub CLI (`gh`) for authentication
- jq for JSON inspection
- ripgrep (`rg`) for code searching

### First-Time Setup

1. Clone repository:
```bash
git clone https://github.com/castrojo/bluefin-releases.git
cd bluefin-releases
```

2. Install dependencies:
```bash
npm install
go mod download
```

3. Create GitHub token (optional):
   - Visit https://github.com/settings/tokens
   - Generate new token (classic)
   - Select `public_repo` scope
   - Copy token

4. Set environment variables:
```bash
# Add to ~/.bashrc or ~/.zshrc
export GITHUB_TOKEN=ghp_your_token_here
export GITLAB_TOKEN=glpat_your_token_here  # Optional
```

5. Run pipeline:
```bash
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go
```

6. Build site:
```bash
npm run build
```

7. Preview site:
```bash
npm run preview
# Open http://localhost:4321
```

### Development Workflow

1. Make changes to Go code
2. Run pipeline: `go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go`
3. Verify JSON output: `cat src/data/apps.json | jq '.apps | length'`
4. Make changes to Astro code
5. Build site: `npm run astro build`
6. Preview: `npm run preview`
7. Commit changes

### Quick Commands

```bash
# Run only pipeline
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go

# Run only Astro build
npm run astro build

# Full rebuild
npm run build

# Development mode (requires pre-generated apps.json)
npm run dev

# Run Go tests
go test ./...

# Format Go code
go fmt ./...

# Check for Go issues
go vet ./...
```
```

### 3. Architecture Diagram

Add visual diagram to README.md:

```mermaid
graph TB
    A[Brewfiles in projectbluefin/common] -->|Parse| B[Go Pipeline]
    C[Flathub API] -->|Fetch| B

- Flathub API endpoints used
- Homebrew formulae API

- Rate limits for each

### 5. Testing Guide

```markdown
## Testing Locally

### Test Pipeline Changes

```bash

go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go --app-id=org.gnome.Calculator

# Test without GitHub token (faster for iteration)
unset GITHUB_TOKEN
go run cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go

# Test with verbose logging

## Problem While the site has keyboard navigation, there are several accessibility gaps that affect screen reader users and keyboard-only navigation. ## Accessibility Audit Findings ### Missing ARIA Labels 1. **Search input** (SearchBar.astro): No aria-label 2. **Filter dropdowns** (FilterBar.astro): No aria-describedby for active filters 3. **Theme toggle** (ThemeToggle.astro): No aria-pressed state 4. **Copy buttons** (ReleaseCard.astro): aria-label present but could be more descriptive 5. **Icon-only links**: GitHub/GitLab icons lack aria-label when icon font fails to load ### Keyboard Navigation Issues 1. **Focus indicators**: Default browser focus ring is subtle in dark mode 2. **Skip links**: No "Skip to main content" link for keyboard users 3. **Modal trap**: Keyboard help modal doesn't trap focus 4. **Tab order**: Some interactive elements aren't in logical tab order ### Screen Reader Issues 1. **Release dates**: Relative dates ("2 days ago") lack machine-readable alternative 2. **Stats counters**: Numbers lack context when read in isolation 3. **Filter count**: "Showing 42 apps" updates without announcement 4. **Loading states**: No indication when data is being filtered ## Proposed Fixes ### 1. Add Skip Link ```astro Skip to main content
``` ### 4. Add Live Regions for Dynamic Content ```astro
Showing {filteredCount} of {totalCount} applications {filteredCount} apps

title: Propagate latest release date to app.ReleaseDate from enrichment sources
description:
## Context

Parent issue: bluefin-s1w (Fix inaccurate release dates)

## Problem

When GitHub enrichment runs (`internal/github/github.go:59-63`), it prepends GitHub releases to `app.Releases` but never updates the top-level `app.ReleaseDate` or `app.Version` fields. This means:

1. `app.ReleaseDate` may be empty (most Flatpaks) or stale
2. `app.Releases[0].Date` has the correct date from GitHub but the card header may show the wrong date
3. Frontend falls back through `currentReleaseDate || releases[0].date` (`AppCard.astro:137-141`), which works for display but leaves the data model inconsistent

## Current Code

```go
// internal/github/github.go:59-63
mu.Lock()
// Prepend GitHub releases (they are from actual source, so prioritize them)
app.Releases = append(releases, app.Releases...)
log.Printf("✅ Added %d GitHub releases for %s", len(releases), app.ID)
mu.Unlock()
```

The top-level fields `app.ReleaseDate`, `app.Version`, and `app.UpdatedAt` are never touched.

## Fix

After prepending GitHub releases, update the top-level fields from the latest (first) release:

```go
mu.Lock()
app.Releases = append(releases, app.Releases...)
log.Printf("✅ Added %d GitHub releases for %s", len(releases), app.ID)

// Update top-level fields from latest release
if len(app.Releases) > 0 {
    latest := app.Releases[0]
    app.ReleaseDate = latest.Date.Format(time.RFC3339)
    if latest.Version != "" {
        app.Version = latest.Version
    }
    if app.UpdatedAt == "" {
        app.UpdatedAt = latest.Date.Format(time.RFC3339)
    }
}
mu.Unlock()
```

Similarly, after Mozilla enrichment adds releases (`internal/mozilla/mozilla.go`), the same propagation should happen in the calling code or in a post-enrichment normalization step.

## Alternative: Centralized Post-Processing

Instead of updating in each enrichment source, add a normalization pass in `cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go` after all enrichment is done:

```go
// After all enrichment, normalize top-level fields
for i := range apps {
    if len(apps[i].Releases) > 0 {
        latest := apps[i].Releases[0]
        if apps[i].ReleaseDate == "" {
            apps[i].ReleaseDate = latest.Date.Format(time.RFC3339)
        }
        if apps[i].UpdatedAt == "" {
            apps[i].UpdatedAt = latest.Date.Format(time.RFC3339)
        }
    }
}
```

This approach is simpler and less error-prone since it catches all sources in one place.

## Files to Modify
- `internal/github/github.go:59-63` (if fixing inline) OR
- `cmd/bluefin-releases/main.go` (if centralizing)

## Verification
- Run pipeline with `GITHUB_TOKEN` set
- Check that apps with GitHub repos have `currentReleaseDate` populated:
  `cat src/data/apps.json | jq '[.apps[] | select(.currentReleaseDate != null and .currentReleaseDate != "") | .id] | length'`
- Compare `currentReleaseDate` against `releases[0].date` -- they should match for enriched apps

title: Fix homebrew release text formatting and overflow
description:
The text formatting for homebrew releases looks incorrect. Issues:
- Long text is overflowing instead of being wrapped properly
- Markdown formatting is not being rendered correctly
- Whitespace handling is incorrect

Need to ensure release notes/descriptions in homebrew cards wrap properly and that any markdown content is rendered with correct formatting and spacing.
design:
## Root Cause Analysis

### Problem 1: Text Overflow
The `.release-description` container (ReleaseCard.astro:433-437) has **no overflow handling**. HTML rendered via `set:html` can contain:
- `<pre>` / `<code>` blocks with long lines (no word-wrap)
- `<table>` elements from GFM markdown (can exceed card width)
- Long URLs in `<a>` tags (no word-break)
- Inline code with long strings

The card container has no `overflow: hidden`, `overflow-x: auto`, or `word-break` rules, so content overflows the card boundaries.

### Problem 2: Markdown Rendering
Release descriptions ARE rendered as HTML via `set:html` (line 167). The Go pipeline converts markdown to HTML via `gomarkdown`. However, CSS only styles `p`, `ul/ol`, `li`, and `a` tags (lines 440-465). Missing styles for:
- `<h2>`, `<h3>`, `<h4>` headings (no size/margin rules)
- `<pre>` / `<code>` blocks (no background, padding, or overflow rules)
- `<table>` elements (no styling at all)
- `<blockquote>` (no styling)

### Problem 3: Whitespace
No `white-space` rules on description content. Pre-formatted text (`<pre>`) uses browser default `white-space: pre` which prevents wrapping.

## Fix Plan

### CSS changes in ReleaseCard.astro:

1. **Add overflow handling to `.release-description`:**
   - `overflow-wrap: break-word` (break long words/URLs)
   - `word-break: break-word` (fallback for older browsers)

2. **Add `<pre>` / `<code>` styles:**
   - `overflow-x: auto` on `pre` (horizontal scroll for code blocks)
   - `white-space: pre-wrap` on `pre` (wrap long lines)
   - Background color, padding, border-radius for visual distinction
   - Inline `code` gets subtle background

3. **Add `<table>` styles:**
   - Wrap in scrollable container or set `overflow-x: auto`
   - `width: 100%`, `table-layout: fixed` or `auto`
   - Cell padding, border styling

4. **Add heading styles:**
   - `h2`, `h3`, `h4` within `.release-description`: appropriate font sizes, margins

5. **Add `<blockquote>` styles:**
   - Left border, padding, muted color

### Files to modify:
- `src/components/ReleaseCard.astro` (lines 433-465, CSS section)
close_reason: Fixed text overflow and markdown rendering in ReleaseCard.astro. Added comprehensive CSS for overflow-wrap, word-break, code blocks, tables, headings, and blockquotes. Build succeeds.

title: Add CI checks: linting, formatting, and security scanning
description:
## Problem

No automated code quality checks run on PRs. This allows:
- Unformatted code to be merged
- Linting issues to slip through
- Security vulnerabilities to go undetected
- Breaking changes without notice

## Current CI

GitHub Actions workflow () only:
- Builds the pipeline
- Runs Astro build
- Deploys to GitHub Pages

**Missing**:
- Go formatting check (`go fmt`)
- Go linting (`golangci-lint`)
- Go security scanning (`gosec`)
- Node dependency audit
- TypeScript type checking
- Astro linting

## Proposed CI Workflow

### 1. Create 

```yaml
name: CI

on:
  pull_request:
    branches: [main]
  push:
    branches: [main]

jobs:
  go-checks:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Setup Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.23'
      
      - name: Go Format Check
        run: |
          if [ $(gofmt -s -l . | wc -l) -gt 0 ]; then
            echo "Please run 'go fmt ./...'"
            gofmt -s -d .
            exit 1
          fi
      
      - name: Go Vet
        run: go vet ./...
      
      - name: Run Tests
        run: go test -v -race -coverprofile=coverage.out ./...
      
      - name: Coverage Check
        run: |
          coverage=$(go tool cover -func=coverage.out | grep total | awk '{print $3}' | sed 's/%//')
          echo "Coverage: ${coverage}%"
          # Fail if coverage drops below 50%
          if (( $(echo "$coverage < 50" | bc -l) )); then
            echo "Coverage too low!"
            exit 1
          fi
      
      - name: golangci-lint
        uses: golangci/golangci-lint-action@v4
        with:
          version: latest
          args: --timeout=5m
      
      - name: Security Scan (gosec)
        uses: securego/gosec@master
        with:
          args: '-no-fail -fmt sarif -out results.sarif ./...'
      
      - name: Upload SARIF
        uses: github/codeql-action/upload-sarif@v3
        with:
          sarif_file: results.sarif

  frontend-checks:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      
      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: npm ci
      
      - name: TypeScript Check
        run: npx astro check
      
      - name: Audit Dependencies
        run: npm audit --audit-level=high
      
      - name: Check for Outdated Deps
        run: npm outdated || true

  build-test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    needs: [go-checks, frontend-checks]
    steps:
      - uses: actions/checkout@v4
      
      - name: Setup Go
        uses: actions/setup-go@v5
        with:
          go-version: '1.23'
      
      - name: Setup Node
        uses: actions/setup-node@v4
        with:
          node-version: '20'
          cache: 'npm'
      
      - name: Install Dependencies
        run: npm ci
      
      - name: Build Pipeline + Site
        run: npm run build
        env:
          GITHUB_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.GITHUB_TOKEN }}
```

### 2. Create  (linter config)

```yaml
run:
  timeout: 5m
  tests: true

linters:
  enable:
    - gofmt
    - govet
    - errcheck
    - staticcheck
    - unused
    - gosimple
    - ineffassign
    - typecheck
    - gocritic
    - misspell
    - gocyclo
    - dupl
    - gosec

linters-settings:
  gocyclo:
    min-complexity: 15
  dupl:
    threshold: 100
  gosec:
    severity: medium
    confidence: medium

issues:
  exclude-rules:
    # Allow long lines in generated code
    - path: _test\.go
      linters:
        - dupl
```

### 3. Add Pre-commit Hooks

Create :
```yaml
repos:
  - repo: https://github.com/pre-commit/pre-commit-hooks
    rev: v4.5.0
    hooks:
      - id: trailing-whitespace
      - id: end-of-file-fixer
      - id: check-yaml
      - id: check-json
      - id: check-added-large-files

  - repo: https://github.com/golangci/golangci-lint
    rev: v1.55.2
    hooks:
      - id: golangci-lint
```

Install:
```bash
pip install pre-commit
pre-commit install
```

### 4. Add Dependabot Config

Create :
```yaml
version: 2
updates:
  # Go dependencies
  - package-ecosystem: "gomod"
    directory: "/"
    schedule:
      interval: "weekly"
    open-pull-requests-limit: 5

    directory: "/"

      interval: "weekly"
    open-pull-requests-limit: 5

  - package-ecosystem: "github-actions"
    directory: "/"
    schedule:
      interval: "weekly"
```

- **Catch bugs early**: Before they reach main branch
- **Consistent code style**: Automated formatting checks

# Implementation Design Recommendations

## Architecture Overview

```
Brewfile Parser → Homebrew API → GitHub API → Data Model → JSON Output → Frontend
```

## Component Breakdown

### 1. Brewfile Parser (internal/brewfile/parser.go)

```go
type BrewfileEntry struct {
    Type     string // "brew", "cask", "tap", "flatpak"
    Name     string // Package name
    Tap      string // Custom tap (if applicable)
    FullName string // tap/name or just name
}

func ParseBrewfile(path string) ([]BrewfileEntry, error)
func ParseAllBrewfiles(rootPath string) ([]BrewfileEntry, error)
```

**Regex patterns:**
- brew: `^brew "([^"]+)"`
- cask: `^cask "([^"]+)"`
- tap: `^tap "([^"]+)"`

### 2. Homebrew Fetcher (internal/homebrew/homebrew.go)

```go
type HomebrewPackage struct {
    Name        string
    Type        string // "formula" or "cask"
    Description string
    Homepage    string
    Version     string
    License     string
    SourceURL   string
    IsLinux     bool // Has arm64_linux or x86_64_linux bottle
}

func FetchFormula(name string) (*HomebrewPackage, error)
func FetchCask(name string) (*HomebrewPackage, error)
func FetchAllFromBrewfile(entries []BrewfileEntry) ([]*HomebrewPackage, error)
```

**API Strategy:**
- Use bulk API for initial fetch: `/api/formula.json`
- Cache locally for subsequent lookups
- Refresh cache daily or on-demand

### 3. Release Fetcher (internal/homebrew/releases.go)

```go
type PackageRelease struct {
    Version     string
    Date        string
    Title       string
    Description string
    URL         string
    Type        string // "github-release", "version-bump", "tag"
}

func ExtractGitHubRepo(sourceURL string) (owner, repo string, err error)
func FetchGitHubReleases(owner, repo string) ([]PackageRelease, error)
func EnrichWithReleases(pkg *HomebrewPackage) error
```

**Release Strategy:**
1. Parse GitHub URL from formula metadata
2. Use existing GitHub client from flathub package
3. Fetch latest 5 releases per package
4. Fall back to tags if no releases

### 4. Data Model Updates (internal/models/models.go)

```go
type Package struct {
    // Common fields (works for both Flatpak and Homebrew)
    ID                   string
    Name                 string
    Summary              string
    PackageType          string // "flatpak", "homebrew-formula", "homebrew-cask"
    
    // Homebrew-specific
    HomebrewTap          *string
    License              *string
    
    // Common metadata
    Icon                 *string
    Homepage             *string
    DeveloperName        *string
    CurrentVersion       *string
    CurrentReleaseDate   *string
    
    // Releases
    Releases             []Release
    
    // Source repository (already exists for Flatpak)
    SourceRepo           *SourceRepository
}
```

**Migration Strategy:**
- Extend existing models rather than create new ones
- PackageType discriminator for filtering/grouping
- Reuse existing Release and SourceRepository structs

### 5. Pipeline Integration (cmd/fetch/main.go)

```go
func main() {
    // Existing Flatpak fetch
    flatpakApps := fetchFlatpakApps()
    
    // New: Homebrew fetch
    brewfileEntries := brewfile.ParseAllBrewfiles("/path/to/bluefin-common")
    homebrewPackages := homebrew.FetchAllFromBrewfile(brewfileEntries)
    homebrewPackages = filterLinuxCompatible(homebrewPackages)
    enrichWithReleases(homebrewPackages)
    
    // Merge both sources
    allPackages := merge(flatpakApps, homebrewPackages)
    
    // Output unified JSON
    writeJSON(allPackages)
}
```

### 6. Frontend Updates

#### FilterBar Component
Add "Package Type" filter:
- All Packages
- Flatpak Apps
- Homebrew Formulas
- Homebrew Casks

#### AppCard Component
- Detect package_type field
- Show package type badge (Flatpak/Formula/Cask)
- Adjust icon handling (Homebrew packages may not have icons)
- Link to Homebrew page instead of Flathub

## Configuration

```yaml
# config.yaml
homebrew:
  enabled: true
  brewfile_paths:
    - /path/to/bluefin-common/system_files/shared/usr/share/ublue-os/homebrew
    - /path/to/bluefin-common/system_files/bluefin/usr/share/ublue-os/homebrew
  include_categories:
    - cli
    - ai-tools
    - k8s-tools
    - ide
  exclude_casks:
    - fonts  # Too many, not relevant for release tracking
  api_cache_ttl: 24h
  github_rate_limit_delay: 1s
```

## Phased Rollout

### MVP (Minimum Viable Product)
1. Parse cli.Brewfile and ai-tools.Brewfile only (~40 packages)
2. Fetch metadata for homebrew-core packages only
3. Extract GitHub releases where available
4. Display alongside Flatpak apps with "Formula" badge
5. Basic filtering by package type

### Phase 2: Full Coverage
1. Parse all 12 Brewfiles (~155 packages)
2. Support custom tap packages
3. Add cask support
4. Enhanced filtering (by Brewfile category)

### Phase 3: Polish
1. Homebrew package icons (via GitHub repo avatars?)
2. Analytics integration (Homebrew install stats)
3. Dependency visualization
4. Change tracking (monitor Brewfile commits)

## Open Questions for Implementation

1. **Brewfile Location:**
   - Clone bluefin-common as git submodule?
   - Hardcode path assumption?
   - Make configurable via env var?

2. **Custom Tap Handling:**
   - Start with homebrew-core only?
   - Add custom tap support later?
   - Manual package list for custom taps?

3. **Icon Strategy:**
   - Use generic package icon for all Homebrew?
   - Fetch GitHub repo avatar?
   - Fetch from formula homepage?
   - Skip icons entirely?

4. **Rate Limits:**
   - GitHub API: 60 req/hour (unauthenticated), 5000/hour (authenticated)
   - Strategy: Cache aggressively, use conditional requests
   - Consider GitHub App for higher limits

5. **Build Time:**
   - Adding 116 packages = 116+ API calls
   - Estimate: ~2-3 minutes for full fetch
   - Solution: Parallel fetching with rate limiting

- Detect version bumps in quoted package specs

2. **Changelog Source:** Where do we get changelogs?

description:
## Problem

The website erroneously shows Firefox and Thunderbird (and most other Flatpak apps) as having been released on the day the pipeline ran, rather than their actual release dates. For example, Firefox 147.0.3 was released 2026-02-03 but shows as 2026-02-05 (pipeline run date).

This affects the timeline view, making it appear that dozens of apps were all released on the same day.

## Root Causes

### 1. Missing `timestamp` field in Flathub model (`internal/models/models.go:186-190`)
- `FlathubReleaseEntry` only has a `Date string` field
- The Flathub appstream API returns `"date": null` but `"timestamp": "1770076800"` (Unix epoch)
- The model silently discards the actual release timestamp

### 2. Silent fallback to `time.Now()` (`internal/flathub/flathub.go:400-408`)
- `ConvertFlathubReleases` tries to parse the empty/null `Date` string, fails, and silently falls back to `time.Now()`
- No warning is logged

### 3. Mozilla date format mismatch (`internal/mozilla/mozilla.go:92-97`)
- `extractReleaseDate` extracts the `datetime` attribute from HTML (ISO format like `2026-02-03`)
- Then tries to parse it with `time.Parse("January 2, 2006", dateStr)` which expects a completely different format
- Parsing fails silently, falling back to `time.Now()`

## Impact
- **All Flatpak appstream release dates** show pipeline execution time instead of actual software release dates
- **Firefox and Thunderbird** also show pipeline run time
- **Timeline view** clusters most releases on the pipeline run date
- **Only OS releases** (sourced from GitHub `PublishedAt`) have correct dates

## Fix Plan

### Fix 1: Add `Timestamp` field to `FlathubReleaseEntry` model
- Add `Timestamp string `json:"timestamp"`` to `FlathubReleaseEntry` in `models.go`
- Update `ConvertFlathubReleases` in `flathub.go` to prefer `Timestamp` over `Date`
- Parse Unix timestamp string -> `time.Time`
- Only fall back to `time.Now()` if both `Timestamp` and `Date` are missing

### Fix 2: Fix Mozilla date parsing format
- In `mozilla.go`, add ISO date format (`2006-01-02`) as a parsing option before the long-form format
- Log a warning when falling back to `time.Now()`

### Fix 3: Update `app.ReleaseDate` from enrichment sources
- GitHub/GitLab/Mozilla enrichment currently only adds to `Releases[]` but doesn't update `app.ReleaseDate`
- Propagate the most recent release date to the top-level `ReleaseDate` field

### Verification
- Run pipeline and check `apps.json` dates for Firefox, Thunderbird, and other Flatpak apps
- Verify dates match actual release dates (e.g., Firefox 147.0.3 should show ~2026-02-03, not pipeline date)
- Verify timeline view no longer clusters all releases on the same day

title: Fix keyboard navigation j/k shortcuts not working with grouped release cards
description:
## Problem

Keyboard navigation shortcuts (j/k for next/prev) don't work after page load. User reports that j and k keys do nothing.

## Root Cause (Investigation Completed)

**Location**: `src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro:147`

The keyboard navigation initializes with the wrong CSS selector:

```typescript
initKeyboardNav('.release-card', '.search-bar input');
```

But the actual components on the page use a different class name:
- **Expected**: `.release-card` 
- **Actual**: `.grouped-release-card` (from GroupedReleaseCard.astro:93)

**Result**: The navigation system finds 0 items to navigate, so j/k do nothing.

## Evidence

```bash
# BaseLayout.astro initializes with wrong selector
src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro:147:
  initKeyboardNav('.release-card', '.search-bar input');

# GroupedReleaseCard uses different class
src/components/GroupedReleaseCard.astro:93:
  <article class="grouped-release-card" ...>

# Old ReleaseCard component (no longer used on main page?)
src/components/ReleaseCard.astro:88:
  <article class="release-card" ...>
```

## Solution

**Fix the selector** to match the actual card class:

```diff
// src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro:147
- initKeyboardNav('.release-card', '.search-bar input');
+ initKeyboardNav('.grouped-release-card', '.search-bar input');
```

**OR better yet**, use a unified class for keyboard navigation:

```diff
// GroupedReleaseCard.astro:93
- <article class="grouped-release-card" ...>
+ <article class="grouped-release-card release-card" ...>
```

This way both card types work with keyboard navigation without changing the JS.

## Impact

- **Severity**: P1 (major usability issue)
- **Affected users**: Anyone trying to use keyboard navigation
- **Workaround**: None (feature completely broken)

## Files to Change

1. `src/layouts/BaseLayout.astro` - Fix selector
2. OR `src/components/GroupedReleaseCard.astro` - Add release-card class

## Related Issues

This is part of the larger keyboard shortcuts stability problem. See parent issue for comprehensive testing plan.

description:
## Problem

Currently only 1 test file exists (gitlab_test.go), leaving ~3000 lines of Go code untested. This creates risk for regressions and makes refactoring difficult.

- **Flathub client** (internal/flathub/flathub.go): API fetching, source repo extraction, release conversion
- **Homebrew client** (internal/bluefin/homebrew.go): Brewfile parsing, formula fetching, Linux compatibility checks

- **GitLab enrichment** (internal/gitlab/gitlab.go): Has tests, but could be expanded

- **Models** (internal/models/models.go): JSON marshaling/unmarshaling, custom types

### Unit Tests
- JSON unmarshaling for all API responses (Flathub, Homebrew, GitHub, GitLab)
- Brewfile parsing (valid/invalid formats, edge cases)
- Regex patterns (GitHub/GitLab URL extraction, OS version parsing)
- StringOrArray custom JSON unmarshaling
- Date parsing (multiple formats, fallbacks)

### Integration Tests
- API client retries and timeout handling
- Rate limiting logic
- Error handling paths
- Mock HTTP responses for external APIs

### Table-Driven Tests
- URL extraction patterns (various GitHub/GitLab URL formats)
- OS info parsing (different release note formats)
- Package version extraction from markdown tables

## Implementation Plan

1. Create test files matching each source file (e.g., flathub_test.go)
2. Use httptest for mocking API calls
3. Test error paths explicitly (network errors, malformed JSON, missing fields)
4. Aim for >70% coverage on critical paths

- Catch regressions early
- Enable confident refactoring
- Document expected behavior
- Faster debugging of API changes
